awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Argument Realization and (Non-)agreement
awd_abstract_narration:
The distinction between arguments and adjuncts is assumed to be a universal distinction made by languages and is specifically built into the architecture of many modern syntactic theories. Broadly speaking, arguments are phrases that the verb requires to form a complete meaning, while adjuncts add in optional extra information. Recent linguistic investigation has identified a language that challenges the argument-adjunct distinction as a linguistic universal in two ways. First, while most arguments are weakly distinguished from adjuncts by being marked on the verb, certain typical arguments lack even this as a distinguishing feature. Second, the processes for reducing a verb’s arguments seem to operate through generalized mechanisms that may ignore the verb’s specific meaning, unlike in other languages. The documentation here will form a core component of the doctoral dissertation of the Co-PI. Broader impacts include a publicly available deposit of recordings and transcriptions at a digital repository housed at the University of Texas at Austin. 

This project examines secondary objects and middles within a larger investigation of argument realization in a language that allows at most one object to be indexed on the verb; thus there is currently no distinction between secondary objects and unindexable adjuncts. This project explores three questions about secondary objects: (a) do secondary objects introduce new participants or realize those already in the predicate's meaning; (b) what is the grammatical function of secondary objects and are they distinct from other dependents; and (c) what factors govern which dependent is indexed on the verb? Finally, this project aims for a fuller description of middle constructions, with a focus on how the lexical semantics of the verb affects its behavior in middle contexts, and how such argument suppression interacts with argument realization properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Languages divide dependents of the verb into two broad categories: arguments and adjuncts. The former typically express core participants of the event expressed by the verb and typically have priviledged syntactic status (e.g. they are obligatory and only sit in certain positions), while the latter typically express more peripheral participants of the verb's event and are typically less constrained in where they are allowed to sit in a clause. This divide is essential to the architecture of most theories of syntax and determine the types of operations we expect to affect certain phrases or relationships we expect to see, or not see, between phrases. This project intended to investigate the characteristics of arguments and adjuncts in the O'dam language, an Indigenous language of southern Durango, Mexico. Verbal dependents in the language are not distinguished along lines that typically distinguish arguments and adjuncts, while verbal affixes do cleanly distinguish between arguments and adjuncts, raising two questions: 1. what properties, other than verbal head-marking, characterize arguments and adjuncts 2. do the phrases external to the verb saturate a verb's argument structure, or is that saturation done internally to the verb's structure.

This project resulted in the completion of the Co-PI's dissertation "Arguments and adjuncts in O’dam: language-specific realization ofa cross-linguistic distinction", as well as the granting of the Co-PI's doctoral degree. Along with the dissertation, this project resulted in several peer-reviewed articles and presentations, along with 3 in-progress articles. 

The work undertaken for this project contributed to both our understanding of the O'dam language as well as the distinction between arguments and adjuncts more broadly. Characteristics distinguishing arguments and adjuncts in the O'dam language were rigorously investigated and illustrated. It found that the universal distinction between arguments and adjuncts can be instantiated through entirely language-specific means. O'dam arguments are characterized by permitting discontinuous quantification, contribution towards verbal transitivity, as indicated by the output of applicativization, and verbal co-reference. While adjuncts are characterized by none of those. The project additionally identified that the properties distinguishing arguments and adjuncts do not clearly relate to the overt expression of the syntactic function. Instead, syntactic operations were found to target the verb itself, suggesting that arguments and adjuncts in the O'dam language are only distinguished within the verb and not by the verbal dependents that appear outside of the verb.
